This was Colorado\'s first all-organic brewery. Asher uses high quality ingredients in a socially responsible way. They employ a wide variety of sustainability efforts while proving that top-notch craft brewing can be done organically.

This is an east Boulder legend that brews a wide range of beer. Avery backs up its regular lineup of traditional beers with dynamic sub–sets of other beers: Seasonals, The Holy Trinity of Ales, The Dictator Series, The Demons of Ale, The Barrel–Aged Series, and The Annual Barrel Series. If this means nothing to you, trust us: There is a ton of innovation, experimentation and craft happening at Avery.

When you\'re driving east–bound out of Boulder on the Diagonal, you\'ll see the sign for this brewery to the right, especially at night when it\'s lit up. Definitely pull off the highway to check this place out. You\'ll notice right away a west–facing patio with a good view of the mountains along with a dog –friendly environment. Once inside, look at the bar itself which features countless concert tickets in its design. So you won\'t be surprised to discover, right next to the bar, a stage with an excellent sound system. (Live performances are common here). The beer selection changes up often, to reflect the love for improvisational music.

Colorado\'s First Microbrewery. Yep, all the way back in 1979, Boulder Beer pioneered craft beer for the rest of the Centennial State. Visit today and you will find an excellent range of beers –– from well– known year–rounders to seasonals and limited releases. There\'s a food menu, special beer and food deals on certain days of the week, and occasional live music.

When you enter BRU, it primarily feels like a restaurant. But take note: The Chef and Brewmaster are the same person here. So the Ales take no back seat to the \"Eats\"!. You will find a wide array of beers, all with \"handbuilt\" touches: Natural carbonation, no filtering, and no pasteurizing. Also, look for the occasional \"Chef\'s collaboration\" ale where BRU pairs up with other local chefs to brew a special beer.

Here\'s a brewery that really puts the Craft in craft brewing. The beers here are all farmhouse-style and wild ales, and most are fermented in oak barrels with a house blend of wild yeast. This means brett-forward, naturally carbonated beers. Some of them are dry-hopped for another layer of complexity and aromatics. As for the location, it\'s off the beaten path: Upon entering the narrow parking lot, keep going straight past a handful of other businesses, and beware of speed bumps. Once you open the door, you realize the intimate, candle–lit setting is just right for this sophisticated brewery. Choose from among a few taps, plus an array of bottles which can be opened and enjoyed on–premise.

This is Boulder\'s first \"Brew–Bistro\" which helps make it unique. The interior design and overall ambiance is upscale; lots of seating both indoors and outdoors (the patio even has heat lamps for the colder days!) FATE emphasizes local ingredients in their food… and plenty of good beer. 30 taps, in fact… about 12 of which are FATE\'s beers. For something distinctive and fresh, try their Watermelon Kolsch Style Ale

This brewery thinks outside the box; a visit here gives you a unique, unforgettable experience. For example, when you order a flight of beer, you can opt for food pairings… which means classic snacks: The Cream Ale pairs with Ritz Bits; The Oatmeal Milk Stout comes with a Hostess Twinkie. The bartender is also happy to blend beers for you. Be sure to check out their game selection which includes Table Top Bowling and Shuffle Board.

Part of a string of businesses, this brewery is visible from N. 71st St, and you pull in to Winchester Circle to access it. Once inside you\'ll notice a ton of seating options around a long and winding bar. Behind there, amongst dozens of barrels, you\'ll find additional seating along with pool tables and pinball machines. The vast array of beers on the menu any given day can really dazzle you: everything from German and Belgian beers to stouts and a handful of IPAs.

J Wells\' motto tells you all you need to know: \"Life is too short for ordinary beer.\" At this intimate, dog–friendly nanobrewery you will find quite an array of beers –– especially for a small operation. The ambiance here is simple and minimalist… which helps you focus on beer, friends and a nice view of the Flatirons.

Here\'s a brewery that values bicycle culture … so much so that it shares its space with Green Guru, a bicycle accessories shop. The tasting room here is small and intimate, which is appropriate because they brew very small batches––one barrel at a time. You may find an IPA on tap, along with a stout, a saison, or even a lager. The atmosphere is quintessentially Boulder–– very relaxed––and sometimes includes live music out on to the south–facing patio.

This is the original site of the small chain of \"Sun\" Pubs & Breweries. Mountain Sun features a social, TV-free environment with about 20 taps of their own ales and lagers, plus a versatile food menu that includes vegan and gluten–free options. The layout here is basically restaurant–style, with a small bar area and small patio on lively Pearl Street. They rotate about 75 beers per year so you can look for new releases constantly.

Sanitas is a great place to hang out indoors, outdoors –– or both! Tucked away near some old abandoned railroad tracks, this brewery gives you some things to do while you sip, including games of bocce and cornhole. The brewers here put a lot of thought and purpose into the process, sometimes incorporating organic ingredients. They opened in 2013 with a few flagship beers and the plans to grow both sour and barrel programs.

Since opening in 1995, Twisted Pine has grown steadily while keeping its local hang–out vibe. They brew a wide variety of beers here –– and keep you on your toes with rotating seasonals and the creative use of local ingredients (i.e. the "Roots Revival" is a Carrot IPA!). Look for a wide–ranging food menu and occasional live music. You'll also encounter \"zymeristas,\" Twisted Pine's term for its bartenders; it means they have extensive knowledge and training in all things beer!

Upslope Brewing Company was founded in 2008 in North Boulder with a seven barrel brewhouse. Business soared, so Upslope added a new, larger brewery (with a 30 bbl brewhouse) located in Flatiron Park, which opened in April of 2013. This larger brewery allows them to focus on brewing and canning their five core styles. Their Flatiron Park tap room has a laid-back atmosphere that\'s dog–friendly, allows customers to bring in their own food; they occasionally host food trucks, and have live music weekly. This Flatiron Park location is roomier than their original tap room and includes a \"Work Cafe,\" which can be rented out for private parties.

Here\'s an innovative, artisan brewery off the beaten path. It\'s located in a cluster of industrial-style buildings and warehouses just a bit east of Foothills Parkway. The beer lineup here changes frequently with incredibly unique touches such as: a porter brewed with coffee, cinnamon and fire–roasted chili peppers; a stout brewed with white chocolate and vanilla; and an American IPA brewed with coconut flakes. Next door you\'ll notice a fermentation supply company which was here first––the owners of that place opened VisionQuest once they started brewing beer on the side.

This is a chic place with an open-air feel on a warm day and a cozy feel on a cold day. Named after the famous beer province in Belgium, West Flanders backs up the moniker with a nice array of Belgian style beers. But they round out their lineup with a few American–influenced beers, guest taps and a bottle list. Check out the food menu, too. It has been carefully crafted so the dishes can pair well with the beers.

In the industrial warehouse district of east Boulder… there are Wild Woods! This little nanobrewery is tucked away and worth finding. The husband–wife ownership has created a homey feel to make you think \"cabin\" instead of "warehouse." Each beer is inspired by the outdoors, a concept which leads to a pale ale brewed with whole jasmine flowers.

Join us for the free Lunchtime Concert Series at the Boulder Public Library, Canyon Theater. Rabblefish plays a vibrant mix of jazz, funk, rock and blues — original compositions, with an emphasis on groove.

Larry Lacerte is a ski patroller turned musician from Frisco, CO. Larry performs a diverse mix of cover songs and growing repertoire of originals as a solo artist and as a member of the band, Broke Down Rodeo. His latest release, Dreaming of the Ways, is his first full band studio EP. The album has a roots rock flavor and represents a few of his favorite original songs recorded with his band.

Greg Brown was born in the Hacklebarney section of southeastern Iowa and raised by a family that made words and music a way of life. His seasoned songwriting, storytelling, and music are deeply rooted in that place. He moves audiences with warmth, humor, a thundering voice and his unpretentious musical vision.

Taylor Shae is an 18 year old award-winning singer-songwriter from Colorado. She performs bluesy acoustic-americana music. Taylor released her 2nd album, \“Twenty Paces\”, on March 23, 2018. You can catch her performing as a duo, blending sounds of acoustic guitar, untamed bass, and soul-crying vocals. See her live at The Laughing Goat, an intimate venue where you can enjoy live music and delicious coffee, tea and more!

Bandshell Boogie turns 3 this year, and it will be back bigger than ever with 7 consecutive Mondays filled with music, fun and connection!\nBandshell Boogie is a FREE, community wide outdoor dance series that is all about re-introducing the power of Freeform / Ecstatic Dance back into our fast-paced and increasingly technological modern lifestyles.
Difficulty: Easy to Moderate \n2.6 Miles Round Trip
Difficulty: Easy to Moderate \n2.6 Miles Round Trip
Difficulty: Easy options, or Moderate \n2–3.1 Miles Round Trip
First and Second Flatirons Trail Map
Eldorado Falls at Walker Ranch Trail Map
Forsythe Canyon to Waterfall Trail Map

Hiking the Flatirons Trail near Boulder takes hikers across a green meadow, then up through a notch between the First and Second Flatirons. The climax of the Flatirons hike waits at the end: grand views of the Rocky Mountains.

The trail to Eldorado Falls is a 1.25-mile hike from the Ethel Harrold Trailhead down to where South Boulder Creek winds through the park. This cascade waterfall may not be the most dramatic along the Front Range, but it still makes for a great hike. Hikers can explore full Walker Loop Trail to make this into a more challenging adventure.

Are you looking for a trail that will shade you from the sun on a hot day in Colorado? This hiking trail has got it all to cool you off: decent shade, a waterfall, a brook, a lake, and a canyon. Forsythe Canyon is just outside Boulder and is an easy to moderate hike.

Green Mountain in Boulder, Colorado is a strenuous hike, but worth all the effort. It has spectacular views of the Front Range, Flatirons, and a wide 360-degree panorama at the summit. The payoff is at the peak where hikers are rewarded with incredible views of Boulder to the East and the mountains to the West.

Mt. Sanitas gives you several trail options ranging from an easy stroll along a meandering brook to a demanding trail up the mountainside. It\’s a great social hike, so bring a friend (or man\’s best friend) on this hike within the city of Boulder.
Canyon Blvd & Walnut Hollow ln \nBoulder, CO 80302

Arapahoe Ridge Park is a spacious park that can accommodate a wide variety of activities to have an enjoyable experience. The park includes playground, shelter, grill, picnic tables, tennis, ball fields, RTD bus route access, and bike route access.

Canyon Park is located close to downtown and is the perfect place for a picnic or to take the kids to get some fresh air. The park includes playground, picnic area, basketball courts, RTD bus route access, and bike route access.

Christiansen Park is a great park that can accommodate a wide variety of activities to have an enjoyable experience. The park includes playground, picnic area and shelter, soccer fields, RTD bus route access, and bike route access.

Columbine Park is a fantastic park that can accommodate a wide variety of activities to have an enjoyable experience. The park includes playground, picnic area, tennis courts, RTD bus route access, and bike route access.

The Eben G. Fine Park is a beautiful community park, perfect for a picnic or enjoying a sunny Colorado day. The park includes picnic area, public restrooms, shelter, playground, Boulder Creek nearby, Hiking Trails, RTD access, and bike route access. The shelter area is available for rental May to September. Please contact the number above if you wish to reserve the shelter.

Elks Park is a spacious park that can accommodate a wide variety of activities to have an enjoyable experience. The park includes playground, picnic area and shelter, ball fields, RTD bus route access, and bike route access.

Foothills Community Park is a large spacious park, perfect for a picnic or hosting a party or small gathering. The park includes playground, picnic shelters, basketball hoops, hiking trails, soccer, RTD access, bike route access, and public restrooms.\n\nThere are three picnic shelters located throughout the park. Shelters A and B are in the same area. Shelter A is south of Shelter B. Shelter C is adjacent to the playground. Please note that groups with 51 to 100 people are required reserve shelters A and B. Groups of between 101 and 250 people are required to reserve all three shelters. If you plan on hosting an event and would like to reserve a shelter, please contact Parks and Recreation at the number above.

Greenleaf Park is a great get away without really getting away! Located downtown, Greenleaf Park is still close enough where you can access shops and restaurants. The park includes, picnic area, playground, restrooms, basketball courts, RTD access, and bike route access.
